1.sofaString: Women Will Act To See Factory Law Enforcee                 3-Day Industrial Institute Results In Meeting Called Monday                 As result of the series of discussions conducted by Miss Cora Deng Industrial secretary of the national at the Chinese this week en the subject Women and Children in Industry special meeting has been called for Monday May 4, to which                 of various Chinese                 women s organizations have been Invited for the purpose of taking some definite action in regard to the enforcement of the factory law This will be tiffin meeting at 12:30 at the 392 Nan kins Road Among the women s organizations to be included are the Chinese Women's Club the Wo man s Suffrage Association Na tional Shanghai National Women's Council and the Child Welfare Association On Wednesday Thursday and Friday afternoons of this week groups of women have met at the Shanghai for series of meetings concerned with the ques tion of Women and Children In Industry and what their responsi bility toward them is The chairmen for the three meetings were Mrs Harry Ling and Mrs King of the and Mrs Frank Ma of the Chinese Womens' Club The topic for the first day s meeting was women And Children In Industry In Shanghai The speaker gave presentation of the present situation and the room was hung with charts the results of                 studies naa made by governmental and other organizations which illustrated in graphic manner what the con ditions are in Shanghai industry as far as women and children are concerned The number of women factory workers was as 57% of the total number of factory workers in the city and the num ber of children was given as 9%. Hours of work for women had been found to be according to study made by the Shanghai 11 to 12 hours for 22,991 women out of total of 30.000 included in the study Wages were according to the same study 62 cts day The amount of the wage of workers which must be spent for ties including food clothing and shelter had been given in study made bv the Government in                 cities in China as 82.59 per cent of the total income leaving only 17.41 for all other expenses It was pointed out also that women in Shanghai factories often have only two rest days in month and in many factories the machinery does not stop during the lunch hour so that the women could be seen eating with one hand and tending the machine with the other Charts were shown giving results of studies made in Wuslh and practically the same condition revealed Long Hours Result In Tragedy As to the results of such condi tions in the lives of the women and children workers Miss Deng stated that the- long hours wore often cause of accidents because the worker became so tired that care lessness resulted and accidents followed The long hours also meant that there was little or no time left for the woman worker to do anything for herself as she must do the housework after going home cook the food for the family and jare for the children One of the effects of child labor Is the un employment among adult workers the children being employed be cause they can be had at very much lower wage Miss Deng said that she had seen unemployed fathers at the factory gates deli vering lunches to their children who were paid only about one third of what the father could earn if he were employed instead The life of woman who works eight                 hours was contrasted with that of worker who works twelve hours day the eight-hour worker hav ing time to care for herself car ing for her children in the proper way for recreation and even for study while the twelve-hour work ers having to start her work day at four-thirty of five had little time to do anything for themselves oven having to cut their hours of sleep in order to do the necessary housework An instance was given showing the way in which children arc often abused by older workers or fore men In certain knitting factory in the city small children are re placed beside older work ers for training and when working on the night line they become sleepy and are pinched or hit by the older                 worker In this case small child was punched on the face with the points of scissors which cut it so badly that the blood covered the floor The only thing that was done was the imposition of Ann 50 cts by the factory Improving Industry Thursday's discussion centered around the various means which have been used to improve Indus try The speaker described three ways that improvement hnd been secured the first being through the efforts of forward-looking em ployers the second through the efforts of workers themselves and the third through legislation As an ex ample of the kind of improvements which had been made by employers Mr Rountree of England was men tioned In the Rountree plant conditions were good and even in the rationalization of the industry the human factory had been kept foremost subsidiary industries be                 ing organized to take care of those workers who were displaced by the addition of new machines There were several examples In China where employers had begun the work of Improvement of conditions cotton factory in Tientsin had tried out and found successful three eight hour shifts instead of the twelve-hour shift hat factory in Ilarbln had also improved condi tions through the efforts of the employer concerned Emphasis On Workers' Education In speaking of the efforts of                 themselves to improve thp ir industry the speaker told of how In England the workers had come together themselves through mutual aid- societies first and later developing well-organized and strong labor movement In China the stimulation came rather from the outside first from students and later through the Kuomintang Party Emphasis on workers Education was given as the reason for the strength of the labor movement In Eng land The development of factory le in England was also des cribed and an analysis of the new China factory law given em phasis being put on the special need for enforcement of important articles women and child ren Yesterday's discussion was on the topic of The Responsibility of Women Toward Industrial Ques tions The question was approach- led through the description of the work of consumers' associations in England and the In England the Women's Co-operative Guild had been able to bring about many improvements in Industrial condi tions and the Consumers' League in America had recently secured better standards in candy factories by the printing of white list which included only the names of factories which had good standards The group present discussed at length what done by the womens groups in Shanghai
